entry.title: Why You’re So Anxious About Going Back to the Office
entry.content:
Build a home for everything that interests you

Add the button to your browser to collect articles, videos, and links from across the web. Use our app to enjoy them on any device in a distraction-free environment.

Sign Up

Discover the best of the web

Today’s essential reads

Why You’re So Anxious About Going Back to the Office

Harvard Business Review · 5 min

If you’re feeling social anxiety about returning to the office, you’re not alone. Many folks are feeling unsettled. After over a year of remote work — and seeing our coworkers only on screen — the idea of seeing everyone again in person can feel overwhelming.

T. Rex Was a Slacker

Nautilus · 8 min

How Tinned Fish Became The Internet's Newest Obsession

nylon.com · 6 min

The Resurrection of Bass Reeves

Texas Monthly · 48 min

A Battle Between a Great City and a Great Lake

The New York Times · 23 min

Fascinating stories

The Key To Flirting? It's Not About You

NPR · 6 min

Everyone's talking about having a "hot vax summer," but what if you're instead bracing for a "lukewarm return to awkward chit chat with people you find attractive?"

How Some People Can End Up Living at Airports for Months – Even Years – at a Time

The Conversation · 5 min

Some do so of their own accord, using airport amenities to meet their basic needs. Others, however, would rather be anywhere else – and find themselves at the mercy of bureaucratic wrangling.

What Kind of Burnt Out Are You? (And Why It Matters)

Lifehacker · 4 min

Different types of burnout require different solutions.

Being in Time

The New Yorker · 18 min

How much should we value the past, the present, and the future?

Why Can’t We Be Friends

reallifemag.com · 13 min

Podcasts and other forms of “parasocial” media reframe friendship as monetized self-care.

10 Minutes of Mindfulness Changes Your Reactions

Harvard Business Review · 4 min

It’s a one-second lead over your mind, your emotions, your world.

The Bloody Bubble

The Ringer · 25 min

Zaila Avant-garde won the national spelling bee, but that wasn’t her first real victory

theundefeated.com · 3 min

How to Season Your Cast-Iron Skillet—and Keep It Seasoned

The Washington Post · 5 min

How Teenage Girls Invented Fandom

daily.jstor.org · 3 min
Save these stories in a personal library

Use the button to build your personal library of articles right in Pocket. Read them when you’re free in a quiet, calm space.

Start your library

‘Legally Blonde’ Oral History: From Raunchy Script to Feminist Classic

The New York Times · 14 min

Along the way, adult zingers were edited out, Jennifer Coolidge struggled with the “bend and snap” and the ending was changed at least three times.

How Political Opinions Change

Scientific American · 5 min

A clever experiment shows it's surprisingly easy to change someone’s political views, revealing how flexible we are.

Sandwiches to pack for a picnic this summer

Los Angeles Times · 3 min

Always pack a good sandwich for the road, preferably one that gets better the longer it sits.

Why Do Gamers Love Speedrunning So Much Anyway?

WIRED · 8 min

Between marathons on Twitch and the annual Games Done Quick event, watching people rush to complete games in minutes rather than hours is a compelling pastime.

An Oral History of How ‘Star Wars’ Became a Merchandising Powerhouse

Esquire · 25 min

After Return of the Jedi, interest in Star Wars hit an all-time low. To win back fans, Lucasfilm expanded into novels, comics, video games, and toys. It was a franchising breakthrough the likes of which the world had never seen.

Cookie Preferences

• Pocket’s Cookie Settings

  • Necessary Cookies

  • Analytics Cookies

  • Targeting Cookies

Pocket’s Cookie Settings

Pocket's default cookie settings are:

Necessary cookies - on
Analytics cookies - on
Targeting cookies - off

You can change your preferences by navigating to the categories on the left.
More information

Necessary Cookies

Always Active

These cookies are necessary for our website to function and to support our business. They cannot be switched off. For example, we use them to manage your login state, and our ad partners use them to display ads and measure impressions and clicks. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but this may cause parts of the site to not work properly. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information and unless Targeting Cookies are enabled, ads are non-personalized.

Analytics Cookies

Enable

We place these cookies on your device to help us understand how users engage with our website and product. For example, we use Google Analytics and other tools to understand which Pocket webpages are popular. We also place these cookies on your device to remember your account preferences and language settings.

Targeting Cookies

Disable

Some Pocket web pages have ads. If you choose, Pocket’s ad partners will place targeting cookies on your device to personalize the ads you see here and on other websites. If you play a YouTube video on Pocket, YouTube may place cookies on your device which can be used for personalization.

Your Choice Regarding Cookies

We use cookies to remember your account settings, and for analytics. Some of our ad partners use cookies on Pocket Explore pages, and if you accept these advertising cookies, your ads may be more personalized on other websites. Learn more
